, sometimes called the "Friendly City by the Sea", is a town of 1,426 people (as of 2000) in

, between the White Oak River and the Intracoastal Waterway. The town was incorporated in 1783, and named for Samuel Swann, a former Speaker in the North Carolina legislature. It's on the western border of the popular

tourist region, and is often considered to be unofficially part of the region. The town's main attractions are its beautiful waterfront views and its quaint downtown, filled with boutiques, shops and delicious restaurants.
Swansboro is located on NC-24, about half an hour east of
and just across the White Oak River from
, the quickest route is to take I-40 to Kenansville (exit 373) and then follow US-258/NC-24 past Jacksonville.
Parking in town is free, and many people enjoy walking or biking through the downtown area.

value: , at the base of the Highway 24 bridge, gives visitors a chance to fish in the White Oak River or relax and watch the water. There's also a statue of Otway Burns, a local privateer who built the first steamboat in North Carolina.

content=On Bear Island. Secluded beaches for picnicking, sunbathing, swimming, hiking, fishing and shelling. Loggerhead turtle nests can be viewed as well. 14 primitive backpack campsites, 3 primitive group campsites, 4 sites for canoe campers. A passenger ferry runs to the island between Memorial Day and Labor Day, but pets are not allowed onboard.
The main downtown area is along
, which features numerous shops, restaurants and historic buildings.

, 334 Journey's End Lane, +1 910-326-5106. Offers ecology tours into the Croatan National Forest, and has a dock where you can dig for clams, dip for crabs, catch shrimp and oysters, and set fish traps. A shellfish hatchery, along with the attached four-bedroom bed-and-breakfast, was destroyed by fire in 2004.
If you want to bring your own boat for fishing or cruising, Swansboro has three

. 25 slips. Also has hot showers and a store for fishing equipment.

, Highway 24, +1 252-393-2416. 90 feet of dockage. Also has three restaurants, including the Flying Bridge.

value: in the area, a small city-maintained pier by the bridge and one pay pier.
loops through downtown historic Swansboro and into the Croatan National Forest.

Swansboro is a town that loves its festivals. Among the highlights:

value: One Saturday in mid-March, the Rotary Civic Center puts on the

with all-you-can-eat steamed oysters, flounder, clam chowder, sides (hush puppies and coleslaw) and beverages, as well as a traditional North Carolina pig pickin'. Tickets are $35 in advance, $40 at the door.
At the end of May, Swansboro hosts the
http://www.swansbororotary.com/ King Mackerel Blue Water Tournament
with prizes up to $25,000, and a barbecue cookout for participants. Advance entry fee is $300 per boat.
One Saturday in mid-June, downtown Swansboro hosts
, where local artists display their arts and crafts amid lots of food booths. Admission and parking are free.
On July 4th, be sure to watch the
over the river at 9PM, with popcorn and funnel cakes to munch, and entertainment before dusk.

, held during the second weekend in October, began as a celebratory event when the bridge over the White Oak River was completed in 1954. Since that year, Swansboro has had an annual celebration with parades, a street carnival, live entertainment, arts and crafts, and lots of seafood, with an emphasis on mullet: grilled, fried, smoked and stewed!
is held in early November at Casper's Marina; fishermen are encouraged to weigh their trout alive and release them back into the water.
On Thanksgiving weekend, pull your car up to the riverfront early to watch the
, as a parade of boats decorated in lights pulls into the harbor after dark.

Many people come to Swansboro for the express purpose of meandering through its quiet lanes and browsing the quaint shops. Parking is free, so take your time.

value: content=New books, as well as thousands of used books at half-price. Also accepts books for trade.
content=Live handfed birds (including cockatoos, cockatiels and caiques), bird supplies and cages, toy birds and vintage parrot-inspired jewellery.
content=Offers Americana by local crafters, including quilts, hand-painted furniture, baskets, potpourri, woodcrafts and more.
content=Open daily. A gift and home-furnishings store located in three renovated buildings, offering country crafts, costume jewellery, pottery and handpainted items.
content=Open year-round, daily except Mondays. Located across the bridge in Cedar Point, over 25 dealers sell furniture, quilts, books, toys, decoys, stained glass and much more.
content=Open daily; call for winter hours. Home and garden accessories, perfume, jewellery, candles, Christmas gifts and an excellent selection of wines.
content=Locals claim it serves some of the best fried seafood in the state, and you get a complimentary bowl of down east chowder with every meal.
content=Famous for their secret-recipe sweet-potato muffins. Sandwiches, steaks, seafood and pasta. $6.95 (sandwiches) - $26.95 (steaks).

content=Open daily in season, closed Tuesdays off-season; 11AM-3PM for lunch, 5PM-10PM for dinner. Located on the banks of the river with spectacular views, serving European cuisine with an emphasis on Italian. Try the stuffed bread (filled with tomatoes, prosciutto, basil and mozzarella) and the homemade desserts. Entrees start from $6.95 (lunch) and $11.95 (dinner).

content=Open for breakfast and lunch. Reminiscent of 1950s drugstore lunch counters, serving omelettes, pancakes, burgers, sandwiches, salads, homemade onion rings and old-fashioned ice-cream desserts. A 1950s memorabilia shoppe is right next door. $3.75 - $7.95.
directions=Between the Swansboro Bridges on Hwy 24

content=Wine and craft beer bar, ice cream and gifts, with a beautiful deck overlooking the Intercoastal waterway. Also has a Homebrew and winemaking section.

content=65 rooms, including suites and whirlpool rooms. Outdoor pool, jacuzzi and fitness center. Adjacent to the Cedar Point Grill and Silver Creek Golf Course (golf packages available). Average price $102.

content=98 rooms, including suites. Gym/fitness center, free breakfast, free high-speed internet access, two versatile function rooms for up to 100 guests. Located behind Hardees. Average price is $82.

content=Owned & operated by Dave & Kay Owens, 160 Cedar Point Boulevard. 16 new rooms with sea themes, accessible by car or boat; wireless internet access; refrigerator, microwave, and coffee maker available in every room; cable w/ HBO; A/C and heat; free local calls; family bar-b-que area; boat slips; 90 ft fishing pier; picnic and play area. Adjacent to a public boat ramp.
